Antonio Marino

Research Associate

University of Cambridge

A Bit About Me

I'm Antonio Marino, a passionate robotics researcher working at the intersection of multi-robot systems and learning-based control.

I'm always excited to discuss research ideas, potential collaborations, or just chat about the latest developments in AI and robotics. Feel free to reach out!

Background

I am a postoc researcher in Computer Science at the University of Cambridge, working under the supervision of Prof. Amanda Prorok in the Prorok Lab. My research is at the farefront of multi-robot system, with a particular focus on developing intelligent coordination and distributed control strategies for heterogeneous robot teams.

Prior to my current position, I completed my doctoral degree in hybrid learning-control approaches for multi-robot systems and communication-based systems. The strong background in automatic control and intelligent systems has strongly influenced my approach to multi-agent problems, leading me to develop principled solutions that balance theoretical rigor with practical applicability.

Research Interests

My research sits at the intersection of robotics, control theory, and machine learning, bridging the gap between theoretical guarantees and real-world applicability. My primary focus areas include:

  • Hybrid Learning & Control: Reconciling classical control techniques (Lyapunov, Contraction Theory) with modern deep learning to ensure stability and safety in neural policies.
  • Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems: Investigating "functional heterogeneity" to understand how diverse agents (varying in morphology, resources, or roles) can optimize complex tasks better than homogeneous swarms.
  • Graph Neural Networks & Dynamics: Developing "Liquid-Graph Time-Constant Networks" and analyzing GNNs as distributed dynamical systems to ensure Input-to-State Stability (ISS) in communication graphs.
  • Environment-Policy Co-Design: Moving beyond adaptation to active reshaping, where robot teams jointly optimize their control policies and the topology of the environment they inhabit.
  • Multi-Scale Robotics: Validating algorithms across radically different scales, from autonomous aerial swarms navigating cluttered spaces to magnetically driven micro-robots for medical applications.

Philosophy

I believe the next generation of multi-robot systems must shift from "seeing" to "doing"‚Äîmoving beyond passive observation to active physical intervention and manipulation. While end-to-end learning offers computational advantages, I argue that deploying "black box" models on physical systems introduces unacceptable risks.

My research philosophy advocates for a hybrid approach: conditioning learned policies with provable control structures. By using first-order principles to inherently achieve safety and robustness, we can treat these constraints as design features rather than afterthoughts. I am committed to bridging the simulation-to-reality gap, ensuring that theoretical advances in decentralized coordination‚Äîsuch as dynamic cluster agreements‚Äîare rigorously validated on physical platforms.

Current Focus

Currently, as a Postdoctoral Researcher at the University of Cambridge, my work is structured around three main thrusts:

  • Functional Heterogeneity & Dynamic Coalitions: Formalizing a "holistic diversity metric" to guide the coordination of teams with diverse morphologies and roles[cite: 403, 404]. [cite_start]I am developing frameworks where agents dynamically self-cluster into strategic coalitions to address conflicting multi-objective trade-offs, quantifying the advantage of diversity through a "Price of Homogeneity" analysis.
  • Dynamic Environment Co-Design: Developing frameworks where robots act as a reconfigurable medium, capable of assembling and disassembling to reshape their surroundings for optimal task execution.
  • Physical Manipulation & Interaction: Addressing the challenges of "wild," unstructured environments by enabling heterogeneous teams to manipulate complex objects, including deformable linear objects like cables and nets, under uncertainty.
